column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Find Other Galaxies
#Text=Galaxies are vast collections of stars in space .
#Text=They can be pretty awesome to look at , especially if you can see the structure of the galaxy .
#Text=Here 's five ways that you can find a galaxy in outer space .
#Text=The first three only work in the northern hemisphere , while the fourth only works in the southern hemisphere .
#Text=Steps
#Text=The Andromeda galaxy
#Text=Find the constellation of Andromeda .
#Text=You should see three bright stars in a line , plus a bunch of dim stars .
#Text=Find the star Mirach .
#Text=It 's the middle star in the line of three bright stars .
#Text=Look slightly north and to the right of Mirach .
#Text=A star map will help you pin down the location .
#Text=The galaxy should appear as a fuzzy patch .
#Text=The Triangulum galaxy
#Text=Find the Andromeda galaxy using the method above .
#Text=Go from the Andromeda galaxy to Mirach , then go the same distance again .
#Text=the galaxy should look like a dimmer version of the Andromeda galaxy .
#Text=Bode 's galaxy ( M81 )
#Text=Go to a dark site .
#Text=M81 is very faint - it 's the dimmest galaxy that can be seen with the naked eye .
#Text=Find the Big Dipper .
#Text=This will point the way to the galaxy .
#Text=Go from Phecda ( bottom left of the trapezoid ) , through Dubhe ( top right of the trapezoid , used to find the pole star ) , then go the same distance again .
#Text=The galaxy should appear as a very faint fuzzy patch - if it 's dark enough , and if you have good eyesight .
#Text=A star map is very helpful .
#Text=Magellanic clouds
#Text=Look south .
#Text=These galaxies are very bright - brighter than most stars .
#Text=You should see two large fuzzy sparkly patches .
#Text=these are the Large Magellanic cloud ( LMC ) and the Small Magellanic cloud ( SMC ) .
#Text=If you want to be more precise , the SMC is in the constellations of Tucana and Hydrus , and the LMC is in Dorado and Mensa .
#Text=Telescope method
#Text=Get a telescope and a star map .
#Text=Other galaxies are only visible through a telescope , you ca n't see them with the naked eye .
#Text=Decide on a galaxy to look at .
#Text=For starters , you can try finding the galaxies already mentioned .
#Text=You 'll be able to make out details that you ca n't see with the naked eye .
#Text=I 'd also recommend M51 , the Whirlpool galaxy - a favourite among photographers .
#Text=Use the star map to find the co-ordinates of the galaxy .
#Text=You can also find them on the internet .
#Text=Point your telescope at the galaxy and take a look .
#Text=If you have a computerised mount , just enter the co-ordinates of the galaxy and it will find it by itself .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Keep trying .
#Text=Galaxies are very far away , and this makes them very dim and hard to find .
#Text=If you ca n't find it one night , try again tomorrow .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Never look at the sun .
#Text=If you 're hoping to see images like the amazing photos that you can find on the internet , you 're in for a shock .
#Text=Unless you buy a really powerful and expensive telescope , you wo n't see very much in the galaxies that you look at .
